comments.content: There are tons of Applications that need to access the internet, but when you're using a proxy their traffic will be directed across the proxy too. So, no, it's not 'all browsers'. The answer is fine as it is.
sass forum

Of course cmd.exe will not use a proxy for things like ICMP and DNS lookups. However, cmd.exe DOES respect the proxy IF you make a request to the port that the proxy is configured to use. I just tried it on my Win10 v1809 machine. I set the proxy to my home router (default gateway) IP port 80. I then added *.neverssl.com to the exceptions. I then opened a command prompt and entered: telnet neverssl.com 80, then pressed Enter. The command prompt remained blank as the webserver expected a GET request. I then typed GET / and pressed Enter. The command prompt window displayed the HTML for the home page.
On the other hand, nmap definitely went around the proxy unless I used the --proxies option.
There're tons of apps that DOES NOT respect this proxy setting. You should try cmd.exe and see if the traffic gets through the proxy.

discussion.content: I believe that "bypass the proxy for all applications" should read "bypass the proxy for all browsers." Then the answer makes sense.
What would be the final answer and justification?
Could you please explain why store.microsoft.com will be bypass in the second question ?

comments.content: *.microsoft.com will be bypassed. See the provided info
There is an option: DON'T USE PROXY SERVER FOR LOCAL INTRANET, and https://10.10.0.100 is a local intranet, so proxy bypass
As Lairyy pointed out, the local intranet address is 10.10.1.x , (Mask of 255.255.255.0). So 10.10.0.100 is NOT on the local Intranet. (10.10.0.x and 10.10.0.x are different networks.)
Look at the information more closely, lairyy is correct. 10.10.1.xxx subnet is "local". 10.10.0.xxx must go through a gateway and a router and so is subject to the proxy rule.

discussion.content: Second question might also be confusing. The setting 'Don't use the proxy server for local (intranet) addresses' is ticked, but it is NOT https://10.10.0.100 because the network on the computer is set to IP: 10.10.1.200 with a subnet mask 255.255.255.0. Only traffic to 10.10.1.x will be bypassed

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 10. Computer1 has an IP address of 10.10.1.200 and a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0.
You configure the proxy settings on Computer1 as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

choices.A: all the local computers and the remote computers within your corporate network only
choices.D: only other computers on the same network segment that have an address from a class A network ID
choices.C: only other computers on the same network segment that have automatic private IP addressing (APIPA)
choices.B: all the local computers and the remote computers, including Internet hosts

discussion.content: This should be C.
Yes C, 169.x.x.x is an automated APIPA adress.

Selected Answer: C
the address 169.x.x.x. is an apipa address

Yes it's C. There is no default gateway listed for either IPv4 or IPv6 (there's also no IPv6 global address). One could expand on C and say "any other node on the same segment that either uses IPv6 or has an IPv4 APIPA address".

Selected Answer: C
apipa all the way

Selected Answer: C
I vote C
C. APIPA
Why answer this question changes?

Last week, the answer was letter C, the page admin changed it to letter B and didn't put an explanation of why.

I still believe it's letter C, as we don't have a gateway to connect to internet computers. Although we have defined DNS in IPv6, I believe that the only computers that would communicate would be those that were on the same track and with APIPA

comments.content: an FE80 address is the ipv6 equivelant of a 169.254 address isnt it?

discussion.content:
It's C, but it's not as straightforward as people think:
DNS is configured to use the local ipv6 address, which may indicate that it is serving as the gateway for the network. 
However, in such a scenario, it would involve multiple network adapters and since we only see the one, we cannot assume outside of the data given which is why it's still C.
Clearly C

why won't the website content creators update the answers, or provide feedback as to why they believe their answer is correct.
How reliable are these questions when going for the exams geez
Easily, C.

c.

"After the network adapter has been assigned an IP address, the computer can use TCP/IP to communicate with any other computer that is connected to the same LAN and that is also configured for APIPA or has the IP address manually set to the 169.254.x.y (where x.y is the client's unique identifier) address range with a subnet mask of 255.255.0.0. Note that the computer cannot communicate with computers on other subnets, or with computers that do not use automatic private IP addressing. Automatic private IP addressing is enabled by default."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/troubleshoot/how-to-use-automatic-tcpip-addressing-without-a-dh

C is correct. With Automatic Private IP Addressing (APIPA), DHCP clients automatically configure an IP address and subnet mask when a DHCP server is not available. The device chooses its own IP address in the range 169.254.
I believe, it is C as well but could the "internet host" be referred to as an internal server
This must be C because the address is an APIPA (169.254.0.0 /16) making it unable to access the internet but can able to access other computers in the same network
This one is so obviously wrong. I wonder who supplied that solution, lol. It's the whole point of APIPA, of which, both IPv4 and IPv6 have in this scenario.

C
GOSH :)

I would agree with C also. APIPA address has been allocated so the host machine can only communicate with other APIPA machines. No default gateway so cannot communicate with remote hosts making B incorrect.
internet hosts with no gateway mmmmm, ill go with C
Yes Answer is C. All computers with APIPA addressing can communicate with each other.

Is their some weird Hyper V going on that would cause this to be answer B ? Otherwise like 
all the others have said the answer Should be C
I agree, I thought it must be C as there's no Gateway to access remote clients.

questions.question_text:
Your network contains an Active Directory domain named contoso.com.
A user named User1 has a personal computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 10 Pro. User1 has a VPN connection to the corporate network.
You need to ensure that when User1 connects to the VPN, network traffic uses a proxy server located in the corporate network. The solution must ensure that
User1 can access the Internet when disconnected from the VPN.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
D is the correct answer.
In the Properties of the VPN you can add a proxy setting. The proxy setting will only be active when the user connects to the VPN.

comments.content: "The solution must ensure that User1 can access the Internet when disconnected from the VPN" My guess is that he should not be able to access the internet because network traffic should go trough proxy server located in corporate network? Otherwise you are right.

discussion.content:
Why not D?
we need to ensure that user can connect to Internet without VPN connection

comments.content:
The User1 has a personal computer. You would find a Dial up issue to deal inside the Internet Options and this ensures everything the question is asking us.

I changed my mind about this question. I will mark C with sang-froid :)

discussion.content:
This question is one of the most true controversial question and I believe everybody gets wrong in this.

If you need to make sure that User1 can access the Internet when disconnected from the VPN, then you will do all the settings through Internet Option inside Control Panel.

From out there, inside the VPN settings, you will find VPN, Proxy and Internet configuration as the question is asking us.

Letter C would be a far possible answer but I would mark D knowing that I could be blindly wrong.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D is correct. In the Settings app, select a VPN and click Advanced options. VPN proxy settings is there.

comments.content: No, in that case the computer ALWAYS uses a proxy(setting). But that is not what the question wants.

discussion.content: There is no doubt, B is the correct answer. configure a proxy script is a commen way.
D. is correct. We have this problem at my shop. If you set the proxy for the machine, it will still be on when you disconnect from the vpn. Result is "Page can not be displayed" :)

Why are there so many incorrect answers? Are they deliberately giving us the wrong ones so we'll fail the exam? I bought a practice test before I discovered this website and that practice test also have the exact same questions and and answers. It's starting to confuse me now.

comments.content: Where did you buy the practice test @pd3vlin ?
There is an opinion, that MS specifically spread incorrect answers, to detect cheaters, who use exam dumps.
That is why the discussions are so important

It's because the people dumping the questions and answers are people taking the test - not insiders or something at Microsoft. Since the test doesn't tell you which questions you got right or wrong, you have to just take the information and run with it. So the answers posted with the question dump may just be poorly researched by the original "dumper."

discussion.content:
Agree with D.
In the Properties of the VPN you can add a proxy setting. The proxy setting will only be active when the user connects to the VPN. The question is asking for a proxy server which is only operational in the vpn. When disconnected the computer will use the default gateway.

I agree with D, at first, I thought it was B like others. However, this was because I didn't know about the Proxy you can setup specifically for a VPN connection and ONLY works for the VPN connection. If you still disagree, setup a test VPN in the settings app, go to the Advanced Options and you'll see the VPN proxy settings right there.

comments.content: Thank you! I was confused until I read your post and tried it myself like you suggested :)

It is very tricky question, maybe if we read more carefully we can solve it.
"the solution must ensure that User1 can access the Internet when disconnected from the VPN."
Probably if you configure proxy setting through Settings, it may caused some issues with logic pledged by organization.

discussion.content:
Answer D:
User1 has a PERSONAL computer, therefore he cannot change the proxy settings on the machine and must change the settings on VPN connection.

If this was corporate device answer could be B.
If you go to the Settings app in Windows 10, then Network and Internet and then to Proxy it says that the proxyserver doesn't affect VPN connections, so it has to be answer D.
D is correct.
The answer is D. B is only for WiFi/Lan connections and it even says it is not for VPN connections. https://www.dummies.com/computers/operating-systems/windows-10/how-to-set-up-a-proxy-in-windows-10/
If you change anything in computer's proxy setting it will keep on looking for that proxy even after VPN disconnects hence D is the correct answer.

[ ] A This has nothing to do with firewall settings.
[X] B The only place to configure the Windows proxy is from the settings app. 
[ ] C There is no proxy setting available in the advanced adapter options in the control panel.
[ ] D If the proxy is required to get internet access you can't make a VPN connection either.

comments.content: happyantlerman is correct, its answer D not B

discussion.content: I agree with D.

Answer is definitely D
"You need to ensure that when User1 connects to the VPN, network traffic uses a proxy server located in the corporate network."
The requirement is that a proxy server is used WHEN CONNECTED TO THE VPN. Applying a proxy via Proxy Settings even specifically says "Use a proxy server for Ethernet or Wi-Fi connections. These settings don't apply to VPN connections." Which is contradictory to the goal of the solution.

comments.content: You have missed the point. You need to use a proxy server on the vpn, not the default gateway.

discussion.content: By default, Windows VPN connections use the remote default gateway. Therefore nothing needs to be set there ruling out C and D. It's got nothing to do with the Firewall so not A. Answer must be B although the only reason can be, I guess, is to make sure the Proxy works to allow the Computer to connect to the Internet.

questions.answer_description: In the Properties of the VPN you can add a proxy setting. The proxy setting will only be active when the user connects to the VPN.

choices.A: From Control Panel, modify the Windows Defender Firewall settings
choices.B: From the Settings app, modify the Proxy settings for the local computer
choices.C: From Control Panel, modify the properties of the VPN connection
choices.D: From the Settings app, modify the properties of the VPN connection

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have two computers named Computer1 and Computer2 that run Windows 10.
You have an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) user account named admin@contoso.com that is in the local Administrators group on each computer.
You sign in to Computer1 by using admin@contoso.com.
You need to ensure that you can use Event Viewer on Computer1 to connect to the event logs on Computer2.
Solution: On Computer2, you run the winrm quickconfig command.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: Answer is NO - trick is to enable firewall rules for "remote event log management" on Computer 2 (tested)

Vinnyct's answer is for forwarding and collecting event log. The question here is to view Computer2's event log from Computer1's Event Viewer. In order to do that, we have to enable the Remote Event Log Management first using command Enable-PSRemoting cmdlet. Then 
1) Open Event Viewer
2) Right-click on “Event Viewer (local)” on Computer1
3) Chose “Connect to Another Computer” in the menu.
4) Enter Computer2’s IP or Hostname in the box.

comments.content: I agree with xphan. Correct ans is NO as its not related to Event forwarding and subscription but just to connect to another computer to view it.

discussion.content:
B. No

Explanation:

Running the winrm quickconfig command on Computer2 will enable the Windows Remote Management (WinRM) service, which is required for remote access to the event logs. However, it is not sufficient to meet the stated goal.

To connect to the event logs on Computer2 from Computer1, you also need to configure the Windows Firewall to allow inbound remote management traffic. This can be done by running the following command on Computer2:

comments.content: Actually the answer of this question is YES. You have to run that command on Computer2 anyway.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
NO

The local machine in which will be used to control is Computer1, so you need to enable wecutil qc, if you gonna use a solution like subscription. The question’s command will be used in the remote (the source of information) machine.

I tested this one and WINRM is not needed. As others have stated, the firewall just needs to be setup on target machine to allow it. There are 3 Remote Event Log Management Rules that must allow access.

Event Forwarding: A notification of events that occur on remote computers can be sent to subscribing applications. Event forwarding is not a feature of WinRM, but of the Windows Event Log. Event forwarding becomes available for the first time in Windows Vista. The Management applications, such as Microsoft Operations Manager (MOM) use event forwarding......So I think the correct answer is NO.

Looks to be more involved then just Running that command.
I think the answer is NO. Believe Xphan has the gist of it

Windows Remote Management is a component of the Windows Hardware Management features that manage server hardware locally and remotely.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winrm/about-windows-remote-management

it's Yes.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-server-2008-R2-and-2008/cc748890(v=ws.11)

comments.content:
It is no: 
winrm qc -q on Source PC (computer 1) = starts remote mgmt
wecutil qc -q on Collector PC (computer 2) = starts event vwr collection
